newsitem.title: INDONESIA: FEATURE - Indonesia bonds market set to boom.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Indonesia bonds market set to boom.

text.p: Indonesia's bond market is set to boom following a surge in the establishment of mutual funds despite the absence of a yield benchmark.
Market sources say a 1996 presidential decree granting tax exemption for interest income and capital gains from investments in bonds listed on stock exchanges is bearing fruit.
Agus Projosasmito, president director of PT Danareksa Sekuritas, told Reuters he was confident 1997 would be an impressive year for the fast developing bond market.
"I'm very optimistic that the bond market will boom this year. There will be some 2.0 trillion rupiah ($840.6 million) of bonds to be issued this year through Danareksa alone," Projosasmito said.
He said this was only the amount already confirmed.
"We are also in negotiations for some other deals which will further boost bond issues this year," Projosasmito said, adding he hoped this could help fill the demand for bonds by mutual funds.
The same view was also shared by Ari Murhandoko, a director of PT Bahana Securities.
"There is no question the market is poised for rapid growth this year due to the tax rules," he said.
Danareksa and Bahana, both controlled by the government, are among the top players in the bond market.
MARKET STILL LACKS BENCHMARK
Although some market players were sceptical of a truly big bang in the Indonesian bond market, many remained optimistic despite the absence of a widely acceptable yield benchmark.
"There are not enough issuances to establish a proper yield curve in Indonesia, so that is probably the biggest problem," David Tan, product manager of JP Morgan, told Reuters.
But Murhandoko said the boom would be mainly demand-driven.
"There will be a take-off in demand. But it won't be like a developed market because the rush in bonds will be driven by mutual funds seeking high yielding papers," he said.
There is no official benchmark in Indonesia because the government is not allowed to issue bills to finance its budget, which is balanced by law.
The government did issue yankee bonds last year, but this was aimed mainly at reducing funding costs for Indonesian companies seeking funds offshore, especially in the U.S. market.

Central bank governor Sudradjad Djiwandono said recently that the lack of liquidity and a benchmark and the absence of a central clearing and custodial body were among the problems hampering the progress of a bond market in Indonesia.
However, Djiwandono said the government might select one bond issue to play the benchmark role.

At present, some bond dealers were looking at the five-year one trillion rupiah of the state electricity firm Perusahaan Listrik Negara V/A bonds as the "emergency" benchmark, which was trading at 105.25 percent and yielding 15.37 percent.
MUSHROOMING MUTUAL FUNDS
"Mutual funds will mushroom. You can see a lot of firms are setting up investment funds now," Murhandoko said, adding that in the long run this would threaten traditional banking businesses.

A mutual fund is often an open-end management company which pools funds from investors to establish a diversified portfolio of investments. Investors buy the shares at net asset value and can redeem them at any time at the prevailing market price.
Pardi Kendy, treasury head of PT Bank Buana Indonesia, said many fresh mutual funds had been set up recently and the most successful were those focusing on investments in bonds.
"Local interest rates are on a declining trend. We have to look for higher yielding long-term papers, and bonds offer the best alternative," Kendy said.
"We can fund the purchase through the money market. The indisputable attraction is the tax exemption," he said.
The Capital Market Supervisory Agency (Bapepam) said net assets value of 24 mutual funds, and one close-end fund, totalled 2.9 trillion rupiah by January.
"We will have almost three trillion rupiah in six months time. We are in the process of granting another seven mutual funds in the near future," said a Bapepam official.
"The potential is enormous. We are still small compared to other countries."
The establishment of open-end mutual funds was possible only after the enactment of new measures by Bapepam in May last year
